title: Things you only know if you have Borderline Personality Disorder | Metro News
text:
13 things you know if you have health anxiety 
If you knew, though, that when you stood me up by accident because you forgot to say you couldn’t make it that it didn’t feel like a minor inconvenience but like you hated my guts and never wanted to see me again, would you understand why I was so upset? 
The frustrating thing with BPD that I say to almost everyone is I have the rational side of my brain that knows it was a mistake and that we’re still friends, but the irrational side, who is pretty much crying into her gin right now, feels like you hate her, and it’s a constant battle to try and get both sides to talk to each other. It’s hard for other people to understand the depths of your emotions (Picture: Giphy) 
Despite quite probably sounding like an utter nightmare right now there are some positives to living with BPD. 
Because I’m governed so deeply by my raging emotions I’ve become very adept at picking up how others feel. This means I’ll probably notice you’re upset before you even realise and I’ll be there to mull it over, give you a hug or just a quick squeeze and let you get on with it. 
I listen to absolutely everyone when they express how they feel, even if they think it’s a bit silly, because I know every emotion is valid. 
And I think that’s the key to supporting the person with BPD in your life – communication. 
Speaking about how you feel might not always make sense at first but I guarantee after a chat you’ll have both learned something about each other that’ll make your relationship stronger going forward. 
If you feel like you might be struggling with Borderline Personality Disorder or any other mental health issue, speak to your GP or call Mind on 0300 123 3393.
